prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use spectral line mode, no need for high spectral resolution, so a hanning factor of 16 is used. The data rate is low.

The source is lensed into an Einstein ring with diameter of ~1.5" in CO(2-1) line map (Riechers et al. 2008). We choose an angular resolution 0.27", so the source size will be spread into pi/4.0*1.5**2/0.27**2 = 24 beams. Consider that the source structure is a ring, so ~50% beams will not overlap the ring structure, so we choose a beam resolving-out factor of 12. The requested rms will make sure mapping cells on the ring strcuture will have S/N>=3 line detection.

The observed CO(5-4) is 3.740 Jy km/s. We assume a Mrk231 excitation CO SLED as shown in Fig.1 of scientific justification. We will consider the source size and will ask a slightly resolved observations. We will detect the line within source size area with a S/N>=3.
We use spectral line mode, no need for high spectral resolution, so a hanning factor of 16 is used. The data rate is low.

The source size is 2.4 times 1.3 at 0.88mm continuum map (Cox et al. 2011). We choose an angular resolution 0.4", so the source size will be spread into pi/4.0*2.4*1.3/0.4**2 = 15 beams. We choose a beam resolving-out factor of 15. The requested rms will make sure most mapping cells on the source will have S/N>=3 line detection.

The source size is about 1" (Momjian et al. 2007). We choose an angular resolution 0.33", so the source size will be spread into pi/4.0*1.0**2/0.33**2 = 7 mapping cells. We choose a resolving-out factor of 7. The requested rms will make sure most mapping cells on the source will have S/N>=3 line detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(8-7) QSO J0927+2001
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
CO(8-7) QSO J0927+2001
can not observe CO(10-9) CO(7-6)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(9-8) SDSS J231038.88+185519.7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(9-8) SDSS J231038.88+185519.7 very strong source potentially extreme warm SF gas

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use spectral line mode, no need for high spectral resolution, so a hanning factor of 16 is used. The data rate is low.

The source size is 0.57"x0.32" (Wang et al. 2013). We choose an angular resolution 0.23", so the source size will be spread into pi/4.0*0.57*0.32/0.23**2 = 2.7 beams. We choose a beam resolving-out factor of 2.7. The requested rms will make sure most mapping cells on the source will have S/N>=3 line detection.

The observed CO(6-5) is 1.52 Jy km/s (Wang et al. 2013), very strong. We assume a Mrk231 excitation CO SLED as shown in Fig.1 of scientific justification. We will consider the source size and will ask a slightly resolved observations. We will detect the line within source size area with a S/N>=3.

We choose a beam resolving-out factor of 2.1. The requested rms will make sure most mapping cells on the source will have S/N>=3 line detection.

The observed CO(6-5) is 1.52 Jy km/s (Wang et al. 2013), very strong. We assume a Mrk231 excitation CO SLED as shown in Fig.1 of scientific justification. We will consider the source size and will ask a slightly resolved observations. We will detect the line within source size area with a S/N>=3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: At highest-z the ISM are very different from present Universe. High-J CO spectral energy distribution (SLED) is the potentially best diagnostic of dense warm star-forming gas and active galactic nucleus (AGN). We proposal high-J CO observations at the highest redshifts in CO-bright starburst+AGN systems. We will determine the shape of CO SLED with CO J=7-6 to J=11-10, which would provide strong constraints on the extremely excitated ISM and the interplay of dense gas and star formation and AGN. Herschel has observed numerous CO SLED covering from J=4-3 to J=13-12 in the local universe, leading to much detailed models and theories of CO excitation. However, at high-z, even in these brighest starburst+AGN systems, we still can not well characterize the highly excited component, because of the lack of J~10 detections. Our observation will validate various models e.g. Narayana & Krumholz (2015), Bournaud et al. (2014), and seek for the evolution of the dense warm star-forming gas since the very early epoch to local starbursts, AGNs, and star-forming spirals.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
